at the same num_pass ,though it's faster but it is not convergent when i use MKL2017

@lilhope ,Thanks for your reply .It seems I mislead you.For the last sofemaxoutput layer ,we konw it's a loss layer and softmax layer,so where I can see the loss function and how to print the loss value?

@sbodenstein hello I didn’t see any changes when I set OMP_THREAD_NUM if I did not use MKL, but  if I added the ctx it was promoted obviously. In the other hand when I use MKL the model is not convergence at the same epoch though it really becomed faster  as the OMP_THREAD_NUM set
If I don't say it clear,Or you can see the issue #1915 ,I want print the softmaxoutput loss(the cross entropy loss?)Appreciative If you can give some helps.
Solve https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/5255. It should be add_n as add_n is used here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/tensor/elemwise_sum.cc#L55-L56.

@Arielnabai Correct me if I'm wrong. Do you want to print the loss for every mini-batch as Metric prints the accumulated loss(average over all, and reset when an epoch starts). The easiest way I think is to print the loss when Metric calculates it. You can rewrite your own Metric by following some metrics [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/metric.py). Take [CrossEntropy](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/metric.py#L326) for an example. you can print the loss when it calculates the loss in this [line](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/metric.py#L343)(which is a sum not an average).

@yajiedesign Many thanks! I think you are right, I tested Linux and Windows on the same machine with 2 TTX, the problem both exists on two OS. Could you please tell me how to `change it into a multithreaded mode`? I found that when I use two cards, the get_batch() function time cost is also doubled, cc @precedenceguo

@lincolnBush In MXNet, this is achieved via `mx.sym.MakeLoss` http://mxnet.io/api/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.MakeLoss. You can first construct the loss function with some basic symbols and use MakeLoss to get a loss symbol that will pass-back gradient.
The implementation of sampling op may be helpful https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/tensor/sample_op.h#L180.
@janelu9 Have you turned on the MKL2017 experimental flag? I cannot get my network converge after turning this flag on.

Thank you very much. Is there any examples for that.

@lilhope  hello , I  met the same problem . I want to print the loss ,but I don't konw how to use mx.symbol.Group([softmaxout,mx.symobl.BlockGrad(loss)]) and  eval_metric .Can  you share your naive code to  2195240001@qq.com ? Thank you!

mxnet is not as,same as tensorflow,The`Variable` is different from tensorflow's Variable(which often used as the weight or bias in a layer),mxnet's`Variable` often used for network's input. After you create your symbol,you can list all parameters' name use `symbol.list_arguments()`,create a dict,for example,`arg_params`,initialize your by this way:`arg_params['conv1_weights']=mx.random.normal(0,1,shape=shape)`,then create your module use those parameters.
This is exactly what I wanted. Thanks a lot!
`mx.sym.Variable` can be used to construct the model parameter.  @KangHsi Could you give us a reproducible example?

@sxjscience 
Problem actually  has been solved(I'm not sure, but no exception arised) after I follow @lilhope suggestion and try this in my net symbol:
```
fgt = mx.sym.Variable(name=name + '_fgt', shape=[128, num_filter, w, h], wd_mult=0.0002)
arg_params=fgt.list_arguments()
arg_params[0]=mx.initializer.Xavier(rnd_type='gaussian', factor_type="avg", magnitude=2)
```
I'll close this issue soon. By the way, I wonder if this is a common way to create customized learnable weights in MXNet?
thanks!

@KangHsi The `fgt = mx.sym.Variable(name=name + '_fgt', shape=[128, num_filter, w, h], wd_mult=0.0002,
                                init=mx.initializer.Xavier(rnd_type='gaussian', factor_type="avg", magnitude=2))` way should be supported by the latest version of MXNet. I feel that there may be some bugs if it raises an error.

I wanted to compare the speed ups from prefetching. Is there a programmatic way to set the engine? Or only through ENV variables? 

Also, then still doesn't give a layer by layer timing, is there a call back or something I can run at the end of each symbol to display/collect the time, and/or the processing time?

But, I use the module the max bucket_key to predict the DataIter() with the max bucket_key, it also has the same error:
```
data_val = bucket_io.PredictBucketSentenceIter(data_vocab, label_vocab,[190], init_states,devs)
haozl, arg_params, aux_params = mx.model.load_checkpoint(model_prefix, model_epochs)
haozl.bind(data_shapes=data_val.provide_data, label_shapes=data_val.provide_label)
haozl.set_params(arg_params, aux_params) 
```
the error is 

 haozl.bind(data_shapes=data_val.provide_data, label_shapes=data_val.provide_label)
TypeError: bind() got an unexpected keyword argument 'data_shapes'

I test the data_val.provide_data is the (1,190)
Thanks for suggestion, I will try it.
Hi, what is the CUDNN version you use? Also, what GPU?
I can't reproduce this on cudnn 5.1 and gtx1080.
Mine is on CuDNN 5.1.3, CUDA 7.5, Driver 352.99, on K80

I was using the wrong syntax. The right way to do it is:

```
symbol, _, _ = sym_gen(data_train.default_bucket_key)
g = mx.viz.plot_network(symbol)
g.render()
```

I also prefer copying mxnet.cpp directly to using submodule, as it allows direct reference to dependencies like c_api.h and dmlc-core. However, this will diverge the cpp package into two versions, one in dmlc/mxnet.cpp, and the other one in dmlc/mxnet, which is confusing. Maybe we can just move all the development to mxnet?
Yes. We can mark mxnet.cpp as discontinued.
@javelinjs the scalatest passed for the regular cpu run, but not for cpu w/ MKL?
In the mxnet Windows installation page it says: "Use CMake to create Visual Studio solution in ./build". What is the command for doing this?
mkdir build; cd build; cmake ..

I went back and re-read the opencv docs on imencode and imdecode.  opencv only supports uint8 and uint16 formats for all image encoding and decoding.  If we wanted an alternative image io format, one that can use a larger variety of dtypes, it think we need to look outside opencv.

* NDArrays load very fast, but the files are quite large (unsure if there is a way to change this), and does not offer compression?
* Pillow supports a [lot of formats ](http://pillow.readthedocs.io/en/latest/handbook/image-file-formats.html), but it is python only, and I would want to test what formats+dtypes it can actually save/read.  Given that imagerecio can be handled mostly in python now, python only might not be a problem (for the python platform).

I would want the final result of all this is fast i/o such as those offered by RecordIO.
I doesn't matter what format cudnn supports. You can use opencv to decode into a temporary buffer of whatever type and convert it to the target output format mxnet supports
Activation(act_type='relu')
Im saying, that if you want to save/read dtypes on disk that are not uint8 or uint16, you cannot use opencv for img encoding or decoding. Once they are loaded, it doesn't matter, you are correct.

per discussion with zack, we should add make these activation functions individual operators, such as `sym.relu` and `sym.sigmod`.

besides, we should also add lower case alias to these neural network functions, this is consistent with google python style.

Ok, it is not BatchNorm issue. But I realized, where may be the problem. When I take trained model and apply it on portion of original data (without undersampling of majority class), then I get test error close to the validation error (but with poor precision).
But when I undersample testing data set as well, then I get 44 %.
If anyone have a hint, how to proceed, I would appreciate any suggestions. Otherwise this thread can be closed/deleted, because it is probably not mxnet related.
Anyway, thanks for your time and effort.

Ok. Let's use some constant like 32 or 64.
My only concern is this will prevent cuda-memcheck from catching some bugs.

@KangHsi ,I often use this code:
```
>>> import mxnet as mx
>>> 
>>> a = mx.sym.Variable('data')
>>> b = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=a,name='fc1',num_hidden=100)
>>> data_shape = {'data':(256,64)}
>>> arg_shape,_,_ = b.infer_shape(**data_shape)
>>> arg_shape
[(256L, 64L), (100L, 64L), (100L,)]
>>> b.list_arguments()
['data', 'fc1_weight', 'fc1_bias']
```
you can get a map of all variables.Then create the dict,initialize all parameters as you want.
You don't need to create all learnable parameters by yourself,It will be create automatically.
Generally good idea. Need to make it clear that this is slow though

This is equal to eval in TF. I think it is not hurt.

@javelinjs @lxn2 MKL python unit tests have been fixed in #5085 #5088 #5144, just FYI

@Godricly , yes, I they do share the same parameters, no problem with params, the problem with the saving of the symbol. Bucketing module has several modules under the hood and
in the base_module the checkpoint function is called with self.symbol which is in the case of the bucketing module self._curr_module.symbol. Now _curr_module switches depending on randomly shuffled data. So whatever module happen to be current at the end of the epoch will have its symbol dumped into ..-symbol.json. I think in order to reload the net state without re-reading the data and reconstructing the buckets info we do need to save all symbols for all sub modules.
I have made a WAR for this but I'm worried about fully testing it, keeping it up to date in the future, and performance degradation due to use of Thrust.
